open-altruists society. People who are dedicated to being open (honest) and helping others regardless of religious creed. Being an open-altruist means that you wear a necklace with a code that can be scanned with a mobile phone (and a pin code), so that others can see your profile, and list deeds/misdeeds about you. Or deeds and misdeeds can only be reported by ratified open-altruists, and so being given membership gives you a credibility that should encourage others to co-operate with you. the open-society: almost like a belief system, never claiming perfection, always working for improvement through honesty and openness...

Advert tax (?and advert subsidies?): adverts that are thought to contribute towards a cost that the state will have to deal with, i.e. obesity, bulimia, etc., will have to pay a tax, and that money will go towards the NHS. These taxes wouldn't be managed at the state level, private companies could be allowed to classify which tax brand the advert goes into; BUT; the government would be able to fine the companies if they demonstrably fail to uphold the law. The companies can upload processed advert applications onto a government host. Any adverts that are NOT registered will definitely be fined. The question is whether this begins with television adverts; and then slowly extends to newspaper adverts etc. The good thing about this law would be that companies can't threaten to go abroad, the adverts in the country that they are displayed are taxed.
